citation.article-title: Meiothermus cerbereus sp. nov., a new slightly thermophilic species with high levels of 3-hydroxy fatty acids.

p.s: Description of Meiothermus cerbereus sp. nov.

Meiothermus cerbereus (cer.be.re'us. L. adj. cerbereus, the monstrous dog Cerberus that guarded the mythological Greek Hades, so named because of the difficulty we had in growing the strains of this species in liquid medium)
Meiothermus cerbereus strains have rod-shaped cells of variable length which are 0.5 to 0.8 (strains GY-1T and GY-5) μm wide.
Long filaments are also present.
Gram stain is negative.The cells are nonmotile, and spores are not formed.
Colonies on Themus medium with and without sodium thiosulfate are red-orange pigmented and 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 72 h of growth.
Cysteine, thiosulfate, or thioglycolate is required for growth of strains GY-1T and GY-5 in liquid medium.
Growth occurs between 35 and 60°C; the optimum growth temperature for strain GY-1T is about 55°C.
The optimum pH is about 7.5; growth does not occur at pH 5.0 or 10.5.

The major fatty acids are 15:0 iso and 15:0 anteiso and 17:0 iso and 17:0 anteiso; 3-OH fatty acids are present in higher levels than 2-OH fatty acids when strains are grown in Thermus agar without thiosulfate.
All strains are oxidase positive and catalase negative.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite. α- and β-galactosidase positive.
Elastin, fibrin, casein, and hide powder azure are hydrolyzed.
Degradation of arbutin and esculin is positive.
Strains GY-1T and GY-5 utilize D-glucose, D-fructose, D-mannose, D-galactose, D-melibiose, D-cellobiose, D-trehalose, maltose, lactose, sucrose, pyruvate, L-glutamate, and L-proline.

Strains GY-1T and GY-5 do not hydrolyze starch or utilize D-raffinose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, D-xylose, glycerol, ribitol, succinate, malate, citrate, myo-inositol, L-asparagine, L-serine, L-glutamine, L-arabinose, L-rhamnose, and L-arginine.
The DNA of strain GY-1T has a G+C content of 60.9 mol%.
This bacterium was isolated from hot springs in the Geysir area of Iceland.
Strain GY-1T has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismeh und Zellkulturen, Braunschweig, Germany, as strain DSM 11376.
Strain GY-5 (DSM 11377) is a reference strain of this species.
